5.0.0-alpha5.
Initial commit of README.md, build structure and test framework.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Document requirement for vm.max_map_count

Elasticsearch 5.0 onwards requires a high setting for
vm.max_map_count[1]

Document this properly.
Also ensure a proper exit code is returned if tests fail.

[1]: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/4398/files

data.message:
Ensure that builds return correct exit 0

`docker-compose up` does not propagate the exit code to the shell, so
prefer `docker-compose run` for the tester container.

data.message:
Build ES image with x-pack

With x-pack we need tests to take security into
consideration. Additionally the cluster health tests behave differently
on single node as Elasticsearch will always have some indices.

Committing `test_xpack_basic_index_crud.py` with xpack specific test
cases; adjusting the es_acceptance.py library but it remains compatible
for the non x-pack version of tests.

data.message:
Publish port 9200 for elasticsearch1

Users find the docker-compose.yml definitions useful, apart from their
intended use for tests, to quickly spin up single or cluster local
environments.

Instead of using dynamic published ports for *both* elasticsearch1 and
elasticsearch2, publish 9200 for the exposed port 9200 of elasticsearch1
as a convenience.

Also clarify the need to change the default password in docs.

data.message:
Allow setting ES conf params from env vars

Elasticsearch parameters normally defined in elasticsearch.yml can be
also defined as cli params with -E. This can be already be used by
defining the CMD as `bin/elasticsearch -E<param1=value1> ...`

Add capability to also define ES params as env vars.
This is some we are already doing in Kibana and is a well established
pattern in Docker.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Better parsing for ES environment variables

As discussed in
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-docker/pull/10#discussion_r81683781
the solution with case is not foolproof.

Use regexp to present env vars as elasticsearch -E cli params. Valid ES
env vars are in lowercase, and have at least two word stems separated by
a dot.

Also fix
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-docker/pull/10#discussion_r81683775
and ensure a valid ES env var has a non zero value.

data.Author: Jason Tedor <jason@tedor.me>
data.message:
Remove explicit heap settings

Since elastic/elasticsearch@743b2ed1b2c7166d30dd3dd1721120bd9738a172,
Elasticsearch defaults to having the minimum heap equal to the maximum
heap equal to 2g. Therefore, the Dockerfile no longer needs to
explicitly set the heap size to pass the heap size bootstrap check. This
commit removes this explicit setting.

heap equal to 2g. Therefore, the Dockerfile no longer needs to
explicitly set the heap size to pass the heap size bootstrap check. This
commit removes this explicit setting.

Add prod note for storage driver on RH based OSes.

On some -- mostly RedHat based -- distributions, docker-engine defaults
to devicemapper storage driver in the `loop-lvm` mode which is
unsuitable for productions.

direct-lvm when the devicemapper storage driver is used.

Harmonize Makefile targets across docker repos

all Elastic docker repos.

Switch to `build` and `push` for the corresponding elasticsearch-docker
Makefile targets.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Use ELASTIC_VERSION and unify make targets

All our docker image repos should harmonize and just expect the
`ELASTIC_VERSION` env var set instead of of
`(ELASTICSEARCH|KIBANA|LOGSTASH)_VERSION`.

Require ELASTIC_VERSION instead of ELASTICSEARCH_VERSION.

Harmonize Makefile targets to be consistent with the other Docker
image repos: default target is `test` which builds+runs tests, whereas
`build` just builds images.

Simplify housekeeping target to be called `clean`.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Do not expose ES ports locally during tests

Running the test targets (single-node-test, cluster-unicast-test) can
sometimes lead to CI failures:
https://devops-ci.elastic.co/view/Docker/job/elastic+elasticsearch-docker+5.0/21/console. This
can happen when both targets are run simultaneously due to a conflict on
the locally exposed port :9200.

Remove local port references for ES in docker-compose.yml. This change
doesn't affect the tests as the test container accesses ES through the
docker network driver.

Retain backwards compatibility for run-es(single|cluster) targets, by
overriding the localhost port definitions with
docker-compose.hostports.yml. This strategy is described in:
https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/2260#issuecomment-151365706

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Only build docker.elastic.co/elasticsearch/elasticsearch:<tag>

Building images named `elasticsearch:<tag>` has the risk of accidentally
pulling library/elasticsearch.

Do not build local images named `elasticsearch:<tag>` but use the full
repo URL instead.

Also instruct py.test to avoid creating temporary cache files.

data.Author: Jason Tedor <jason@tedor.me>
data.message:
Add hack for obtaining cgroup stats

Docker mounts cgroup stats inconsistently with the hierarchy
in /proc/self/cgroup. This breaks the logic for traversing
from /proc/self/cgroup to the stats for a process running inside a
container. In core Elasticsearch, an undocumented hack was added to
support this, for now. Thus, for cgroup stats to be available from
Elasticsearch running inside a Docker container, the Elasticsearch
process should be started with `-Des.cgroups.hierarchy.override=/`.

Add hack for obtaining cgroup stats and comment it.

Relates #25
Relates https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/pull/22757

data.message:
Allow _ in elasticsearch env vars

A few Elasticsearch configurable parameters contain an underscore in
their name, such as thread_pool.

Allow definition of those parameters via env vars and present them
correctly as -E params to Elasticsearch.

data.Author: Bryon Roché <kain@kain.org>
data.message:
Fix envvar-arg mapping when spaces are in value. (#53)

The environment variable to ES option mapping in `es-docker` does not
work correctly when an option value contains whitespace.  This commit
changes the assembly of options to use an array instead of a string, and
then uses a proper all-array-items-to-words expansion at the end so
things like quoting don't need to be worried about.

data.message:
Make elasticsearch2 a data (non-master) node

This change the removes the need to configure minimum master nodes
differently depending on whether one or two containers were started.

Because that logic was previously handled in the Makefile, it was
necessary to handle all docker-compose actions via make. It's now
possible to invoke `docker-compose up` directly, without having to go
through make or set environment variables.

data.Author: Toby McLaughlin <toby@jarpy.net>
data.message:
Re-write test suite

Overhauls the test suite using an object-oriented PyTest "fixture" to
control and test Elasticsearch.

Eliminates side-effects from mutating tests with an __init__ method on the
fixture, and a reset() method which completely recreates the containers
while the tests are running.

Simplifes cluster health assertions by setting the default
"number_of_replicas" to 0. This, combined with an earlier patch that sets
the elasticsearch2 container to be a data-only (non-master) node means
that we can always expect the cluster state to be "green".

data.message:
Add test support for ES in single node dev mode

To help with running tests when ES is running as a single node, use the
optional cli param functionality of pytest to declare `--single_node`.

If true, checks the right amount of nodes and cluster status check is
more lenient between yellow and green, as ES is in yellow state
initially when running as a single node.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Add tests to ensure non ES specific env vars are parsed by wrapper

The es-docker wrapper converts Docker environments variables to
Elasticsearch parameters that are lowercase and separated at least by
one dot.

Ensure env variables that don't match the above pattern[1] are not passed
to Elasticsearch.

[1] The elasticsearch conf params `processors` and `pidfile` are not
relevant as container cpu resources can be limited with Docker.

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@elastic.co>
data.message:
Relax test for setting heap size via env var

When specifying max heap size with -Xmx the reported value differs
slightly from the specified size. This is due to the JVM doing some
calculations for generation ratios, correcting alignment and rounding
the result[1], so we need to be less explicit about this test. It is
good enough if ES reports the max heap size within a delta(set to
64MB) of the specified size.

[1] http://stackoverflow.com/a/28395673

version_tag is error prone as there can be artifacts like

template used for building the Dockerfile as well as the
`docker-compose.yml` for tests, through the Makefile.

Fail a build if the produced image containers any /core* files.

Relates #97

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com>
data.message:
Add acceptance test for bootstrap memorylock

One of the ways to disable swapping on ES is using the
bootstrap.memory_lock=true option.

Add acceptance tests to ensure that this works correctly in
Docker. Note that this option **requires** setting the `memlock`
ulimit to infinity which is possible in plain Docker (docker-compose v2
format) but not supported yet in Docker Swarm mode.

Also remove `NOFILE` ulimit definitions from docker-compose tests since with https://github.com/moby/moby/commit/8db61095a3d0bcb0733580734ba5d54bc27a614d
reasonably new versions of Docker set `NOFILE` and `NPROC` to infinity and
we don't need to explicitly override those ulimits in our test containers.

Finally, remove unused imports for .py test files.

Relates #98

transport.

With the introduction of Docker image flavors, we can use the same
Dockerfile j2 template to produce different static files under
build/elasticsearch.

LF characters combined with j2 conditionals and multiline Dockerfile
commands get tricky. Split COPY/RUN commands setting up the config
files of ES+their ownership in j2 conditional sections.

data.message:
Make `bin/elastic-version` canonical.

Condenses handling of the ELASTIC_VERSION environment variable to a
single location in the `elastic-version` script. This makes
`elastic-version` the One True Way to determine the version in code,
even if it's just spitting back the version forced by $ELASTIC_VERSION.

data.Author: Toby McLaughlin <toby@jarpy.net>
data.message:
Move image flavor to repository, not tag

The release manager is built with the expectation that the version tag
of any Docker image will contain strictly the ELASTIC_VERSION. When we
overload the version tag with the image flavour, we break that
expectation.

This patch moves the image flavour from the tag to the repository, so
instead of getting image names like:

  elasticsearch:6.0.0-beta2-platinum

You get ones like:

  elasticsearch-platinum:6.0.0-beta2

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com>
data.message:
Use multi-stage build and replace CMD with ENTRYPOINT

This commit switches away from the esdocker CMD to an ENTRYPOINT.
The ENTRYPOINT (`/usr/local/bin/docker-entrypoint.sh`) combines Docker
+ Kubernetes + Openshift best practices.

The group ownership of `/usr/share/elasticsearch` is now 0, so in the
case of Openshift, or forcing `--user <other_uid>`, elasticsearch can
still run and write to bind mounted directories. The root group
doesn't grant any additional special permissions, so should somehow the
elasticsearch process in the container be compromised, it can't access/mutate
critical files from the host os, even if `/` is mounted in the container.

Optionally, a `TAKE_FILE_OWNERSHIP` env var can be explicitly used to
override the UID:GID of the `data` and `logs` dirs as well, when the
ENTRYPOINT is allowed to run as the default root user (i.e. not in Openshift).

It's still possible to run another CMD, through the ENTRYPOINT, such
as `/bin/bash` to inspect things or directly `bin/elasticsearch -Ex.y=z`[1].

Finally, CTRL-C is now handled more appropriately, when using the
image interactively.

There are four new tests to check gid ownership of extracted files and running
elasticsearch with different combinations of bind-mounted host data directories
and process uids.

[1]: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/docker.html#_d_override_the_image_8217_s_default_ulink_url_https_docs_docker_com_engine_reference_run_cmd_default_command_or_options_cmd_ulink

Relates #125

data.Author: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com>
data.message:
More precise detection when user passes elasticsearch binary in CMD

It is possible a user may want to execute some of the binaries under
`bin/elasticsearch`. One example would be `docker exec -ti esdocker
bin/elasticsearch-plugin list` against an already running
elasticsearch container.  Currently the entrypoint will overwrite the first argument if
it contains the stem `elasticsearch`, thus starting `bin/elasticsearch`
instead of executing the specified command.

Be more precise when to overwrite the $1 arg of CMD to `elasticsearch`
and allow user exec other commands that may contain the stem
`elasticsearch`.

Relates #129

data.Author: Jason Tedor <jason@tedor.me>
data.message:
Do not use host network for building image

Today the Elasticsearch Docker build relies on the host network for
building the Docker image. In particular, it requires port 8000 on the
host to be available so that the Docker build can connect to the
artifacts server that is created during an earlier phase of the build. I
ran into a strange issue where the build would repeatedly fail if using
the host network. In particular, the issue that I ran into is that the
setup package installed during yum update could not be installed because
/etc/hosts could not be extracted from the package. It is not clear to
me why this fails with the host network, but once we surmised this was a
possbility and switched to not use the host network, the issue went
anyway. Whatever the issue is, it's inherently desirable to not use the
host network during the build anyway. Instead, we can connect the
containers over a dedicated bridge network and not rely on port 8000
being available on the host. Fortunately, this fixes the issue that I
was running into as well.

Co-authored-by: Dimitrios Liappis <dimitrios.liappis@gmail.com>
